The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition

Foreword
Accountability is the single greatest differentiator between top performers and
everybody else.
This book details The Accountability Protocol, a simple and subtle method that will
massively improve your own accountability, and that of your team.
The Protocol focuses entirely on what you can do. You will always have the initiative to
improve the accountability between yourself and your colleagues, customers, and
others.
Welcome
Welcome to version 2 of The Accountability Protocol: a method for setting and
managing expectations and its enabling tool, the Accountability Loop.
By the end of this book, you'll have learned the behaviors needed to increase your own
accountability to others—and to kindly and assertively ask others to be more
accountable as well.
Let’s define “Accountability.”
When I promise to do something for you, I'm creating an expectation.
Accountability occurs when you and I both agree that this expectation has been met
or handled. An expectation can be handled in any of three ways:
1. I did what you understood me saying I would do.
2. We re-negotiated to a new expectation that I then met.
3. We unwound that expectation in a way that worked for us both.
Some examples:
1. You ask me to pass the salt; I say “yes” and pass you a salt shaker; you thank me.
2. You ask me to pass the salt; I say “yes” but then discover we’re out, so I offer you
our low-sodium salt substitute; you accept this and thank me.
3. You ask me to pass the salt; say “yes” but then discover we’re out and apologize;
you accept this with good grace.

Any other outcome isn't an accountable outcome:
1. We disagree over what was promised.
2. We disagree over what was delivered (and whether it met expectations).
3. I simply fail to perform without unwinding or renegotiating.
4. You fail to accept what I do without unwinding, renegotiating, or a hot wash.
Here are some non-accountable examples:
1. You ask me to pass the salt; you think I said “yes” but I later deny that I did; you
don’t receive salt; we disagree about whether I ever promised you salt.
2. You ask me to pass the salt at lunch; I say “yes” then hand you some rock salt for
de-icing a sidewalk; we then disagree about whether I did what you asked.
3. You ask me to pass the salt; I say “yes” but do nothing.
4. You ask me to pass the salt; I pass you something I think is salt; you profess
dissatisfaction but never explain why or give me a chance to fix the problem.
There are a near-infinite number of ways for expectations to fail. This book shows you
39 major ways two people can:
● mis-set expectations
● undermine performance
● fail to clarify vagueness
● fail to renegotiate
● fail to unwind
● fail to learn
And, we'll equip you with behaviors, techniques, and Job Aids (checklists and other
tools) to help you create and sustain Accountability for yourself and all those with whom
you work.
Why master Accountability?
Accountability strikes at the heart of both performance problems and morale
problems.
Exercise:
Think about a time someone really let you down at work.

Everyone hates being let down
For most people, being let down is one of the biggest problems at work. Here's a real
example from a student:
Expectation that was set: I was asked to create a simple CRM spreadsheet to
present at our business development working meeting.
What actually happened: I worked over the weekend on it. During the meeting the
following week, my work was ignored (not reviewed) and another solution was
presented—by the person who asked me to create my solution.
How this person felt: Disempowered. Like I wasted time. Disrespected. Frustrated.
While the specific details vary widely, this person's emotional experience is typical. Low
Accountability and mismatched expectations are a huge source of drama, ill will, low
morale, damaged trust, and self-inflicted chaos in the workplace.
Here are a few more answers students gave when asked, “What was the impact of your
specific example of Low Accountability?”
● Time wasted
● Not meeting KPIs
● Customer dissatisfaction and lost revenue
● Loss of revenue and customer goodwill
● Feelings of inadequacy
● Loss of respect and trust for my organization
● High stress, having to re-prioritize to-do list
● Frustration
● You lose motivation to excel
● Spent time I didn't have.
● Morale drops among staff. We even had staff that wouldn't volunteer to help with
other projects after their experience.
● Stressed, frustrated
● Frustrated, or like working relationship has been damaged
● Embarrassed
● Frustration over participation, always asking how we/I can improve this
● Looking for a new job
● My trust is gone
● Disheartened
● It makes me question their work ethic

Everyone Loves High Accountability
And at the same time, experiencing an example of High Accountability is wonderful.
Here are those same students, describing what this was like for them:
● Pride
● I was very grateful and they enjoyed helping me out.
● We all sacrificed, which led to great team bonding.
● Checking item off the list, one less thing to worry about, gratefulness
● The team felt united
● Gratitude
● Pride all around
● Employees awarded with Kaizen during plantwide meeting. I was astounded that
they could pull that off. Sense of pride and ownership.
● pleased and surprised
● Business partnership is stronger, feels good to ask for that thing again, knowing
how to ask for it or when
● We felt capable of overcoming anything we put our minds to.
● Accomplishment
● Communications were open and direct which moved the project faster and we felt
very successful at the end.
● Ownership
● Sense of purpose
● My Boss said I did an amazing job on training someone. Impact for us was we
didn't have to watch over their shoulder the whole time and then I can move on
to something else to make the work to go faster.
● Great
The point is, Low Accountability creates lousy results and a low-morale work
environment. The best people leave, and good people don't want to join.
High Accountability creates great results and an energized, high-morale work
environment. The best people stay, and good people are eager to join.

Preconditions for Accountability
We know that we have Accountability when the Doer and the Asker both agree the Doer
did what the Asker asked for.
Simple as this sounds, it won’t happen on its own -- preconditions must exist. Here are
the biggest. A more detailed treatment of Preconditions is covered in Appendix I.
Ownership or Roles
Before you embark on an Accountability journey, be sure your roles are clear. If you see
problems with Accountability, check for role clarity and ownership of results.
Basic Trust
The Accountability Protocol only works when the Asker and Doer have some baseline
level of mutual trust. This level of basic trust doesn’t need to be all that high. Even
people who might normally mistrust each other can still come together and cooperate
effectively. (Think of the World War I Christmas cease-fires that happened
spontaneously up and down the trenches.)
Clarity (and Context)
In his book Conversations for Action (the inspiration for The Accountability Protocol),
Fernando Flores referred to the need to share a “context of obviousness.”
The Asker and the Doer need to share enough clarity and context to understand the
requests being made and the agreement or expectation they are creating.
If you see problems with Accountability, and the two actors have perhaps never worked
together or haven’t done this task before, check for a lack of clarity around context.
Mental Fitness (non-victimhood)
For as long as neither of our actors -- Asker and Doer -- are in a Victim or other
Sabotaged state (they are in Neutral or Sage mode), the Accountability Protocol can
always be made to work.
If both are Sabotaged, the Accountability Protocol is unlikely to work. (But with
practice, it’s possible.)

In other words, a precondition for reliable usage of the Accountability Protocol is that
the two actors be Neutral or better. If you see breakdowns, you may need to check for
Sabotage.
Doability
The work being requested by the Asker must be Doable by the Doer.
An optimistic or naive Doer (or one who has been hijacked by a Pleaser Saboteur and is
motivated to please rather than to make a well-grounded commitment) may say “yes”
despite the non-doability of the task, or before confirming doability.
See the chapter on the Negotiate phase, where Doability must be confirmed.

Overview of the Accountability Loop
To create a Culture of High Accountability—or even to just raise your own, or effectively
coach someone else to raise theirs—you must understand the hidden structure
underlying all forms of Accountability.
Accountability is structured as a Loop.
The Accountability Loop consists of four major phases:
● Initiate
● Negotiate
● Perform
● Accept
This structure holds for all instances when two people agree that one of them will do
something for the other.
Here's what happens in each Phase.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 9 of 47

-- 9 of 47 --

The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition
Initiate
One person takes on the Role of Asker. As Asker, they declare a desire for an outcome or
activity. This declaration creates a new possibility in the world. The artifact that marks
the end of this Phase is the “Request for Performance.”
Negotiate
The second person takes on the Role of Doer. They respond to the Asker's Request by
indicating a willingness to enter dialog, and the two parties engage in Negotiation.
During this Phase, the two should surface the Asker's "Conditions of Satisfaction" that, if
met, would complete the Loop. They also need to surface the Doer's "Needs and
Constraints" that will empower the Doer to Perform. This conversation creates an
expectation. The artifact that marks the end of this Phase is the “Mutual Agreement
of Performance.”
Perform
The Doer now engages in the work. They may need to ask clarifying questions of the
Asker, and events may force a renegotiation. The Doer may also become an Asker and
enlist the help of subcontractors or helpers. This opens Sub-Loops that nest inside the
main Loop. This work creates results in the world. The artifact that marks the end of this
Phase is the "Report that Performance is Complete."
Accept
The Asker has been notified and is now expected to examine the work product and
inform the Doer if indeed the Conditions of Satisfaction have been met. They may ask
for re-work, which can re-open Negotiation. The two parties can each look at how they
contributed to the outcome and how each can do better in the future. If the experience
harmed their working relationship, repair may be called for. The artifact that marks the
end of this Phase is the "Report that Performance is Accepted." (Note that
performance can also be rejected at this point.)
Each of these Phases has Best Practices
In the pages that follow you'll be able to learn the best practices of creating High
Accountability, phase by phase.
Accountability Creates Coordination
You fix coordination issues by:
1. Making explicit requests
2. Making explicit promises (commit, decline, or counter-offer)
3. Tracking commitments clearly; and

Phase 1: Initiate
When one person Initiates a request for another person to take an action, that first
person takes on the Role of Asker. The other person takes the Role of Doer.
This phase culminates in an artifact: a Request for Performance. This may take the
form of an email, a spoken request, etc.
Before the Request occurs, this Loop has not yet sprung into existence. It is only a
thought in the Asker's mind.
Once the Request is stated, there is now a declaration of a new possibility.
Even if nobody has yet stepped up to be Doer, the Asker has created a new tension in the
world, between their words, and their unmet desired outcome.
When John F. Kennedy declared...
I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before
this decade is out, of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely
to the Earth.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 12 of 47

...nothing had yet happened, other than a massive setting of new expectations.
Initiating well is very powerful. It deserves to be done with care.
Best Practices of Initiating
Here are the best practices of Initiating. These are things Askers can do to create higher
levels of Accountability.
● Gather the facts together first
● Repeat work? Use a template or checklist specific to this task
● Clarify Effort vs Outcome requests (exploratory vs proven methods)
● Share context so others can make smart tradeoffs
● Clarify your Ultimate Outcome (explain how you will make use of the work
product)
● Describe it Visually
● Specify delivery format and method
● Ask for interim work products, status reports, samples
The most common failure modes in the Initiate phase are:
1. Get it Off my Plate Already - the Asker is impatient, more focused on
reducing their mental burden than in setting the Doer up for success.
2. Read my Mind - the Asker assumes the Doer thinks the same way the Asker
does, and Initiates in a way that discourages dialog during Negotiate. (When
the two work together routinely, or share a context of indoctrination—e.g. they
both graduated from West Point—that can work. But it's dangerous to assume;
better to "trust but verify"—which means, to Initiate in a way that invites the
Doer to verify details during Negotiate.)
3. Pass the Buck - the Asker is eager for someone else to take the blame for
incipient failure. This is an "unclean Ask" because the Asker is not truly
desiring the work to be done, so much as they are seeking to avoid blame by
offering up a Doer as a human sacrifice, usually to an unreasonable boss or
customer.
4. Micro Request - the Asker asks for something so small that it takes longer to
discuss the request than to do the work. Wasteful on its face, this failure mode
may hint that the Asker doesn’t trust the Doer with larger tasks, or the Asker is
using the request as a power play—to demonstrate to the Doer that the Asker can
make them do things.

Phase 2: Negotiate
The Negotiate Phase is critical to success with an Accountable Agreement. Whichever
role you play, Asker or Doer, you've got a stake in a good Negotiation.
Best Practices when you are the Asker:
● Do I want an Outcome or an Effort?
● Separate the Outcome from the Method
● Is the counter-offer OK?
● Are they visualizing what I’m visualizing?
● Ask for early updates
● Give Context
● Challenge a weak YES
Best Practices when you are the Doer:
● Do I know a better way?
● No weak YESes!
● What else am I doing?

● Can I commit to an Outcome, or only to Effort?
● Offer visualizations and early updates
● Commit-to-Commit and Conditional Yes
Best Practices when you are the Asker
Do I want an Outcome or an Effort?
By "Outcome" we mean "a well defined result." By "Effort" we mean "a given amount of
work time." If you ask your child "please mow the lawn" that's asking for an Outcome. If
you ask your child "please spend 30 minutes mowing the lawn" that's asking for Effort.
Whenever you have a known problem with a known solution, it's usually better to
ask for an Outcome rather than for Effort. (Workers mostly enjoy finishing things they
can feel good about, and Outcomes provide that.)
But when you're in a more exploratory space—say the yard is new, and we don't know
how long it takes to mow it—asking for a well-defined amount of Effort is safer for the
Doer and wiser for both parties. As the Asker, you can look at the partially mowed lawn
after 30 minutes and estimate the total work much better than you could before any
effort was made.
If you have a well functioning sales process and a trained salesperson, you can ask the
salesperson to "sell 10 cars this week" and you both know it's a reasonable request. But
if you are still figuring out your sales process (or the person is in training), it can be
better to ask for a given amount of effort, as in "sell cars for five days this week using the
new process, and report back on what your experience was."
Separate the Outcome from the Method
Sometimes we simply want an Outcome (sales of cars), and other times we want both an
Outcome (clean room operations) and to dictate the Method the Doer uses.
Asking for use of a given Method is mostly appropriate in Six Sigma or similar
environments where there's strong process discipline, and it's important that the Doer
follow an SOP (Standard Operating Procedure).
In other cases, such as when Doers have expertise and when the environment is more
complex or emergent and the worker needs to use judgment, it's better to NOT specify
the Method too tightly. When the Asker gives the Doer some room for creativity and
initiative, the Doer is free to find better methods, and the Asker keeps their focus on
their true goal, the Outcome.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 15 of 47

(We should always have clear boundaries around what a Doer must not do, e.g.
prohibitions on unsafe, illegal, or unethical behavior.)
Is the counter-offer OK?
Expect as Asker that the Doer may make a counter-offer. Be open to this, but don't say a
"yes" you don't really mean.
Are they visualizing what I’m visualizing?
As George Bernard Shaw put it, "The single biggest problem in communication is the
illusion that it has taken place."
Take the time to describe your desires so clearly that you both can visualize that desire.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 16 of 47

-- 16 of 47 --

The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition
Just because you're asking for a horse and everyone is smiling and nodding, doesn't
mean they're also visualizing a horse.
Don't rely on language unless you have reason to believe you share definitions. There's a
joke that the verb "to secure" means very different things across the US Armed Forces.
When told to "secure that building"...
● ...the Army would assault it from the front and sides with a company of soldiers
● ...the Marines would assault it from the top by dropping a squad of soldiers from
a helicopter
● ...the Navy would send a yeoman with a flashlight and a keyring to lock all the
doors
● ...the Air Force would acquire a 5-year lease with the option to purchase
It's OK during Negotiate for the Asker to ask, especially if the Doer seems overly
confident or vague, "please describe what you're hearing me say that I want."
The point here is not to shame the Doer for hearing you incorrectly. Your attitude
should be, "I know what I intended to ask for, but I need to know what you thought you
heard." Half of the point of Negotiation is to close the gap between what the Asker
thought they asked for, and what the Doer thought they heard.
Another good question is:
● If a video camera were recording you delivering the result, what would it see?
Time spent here is especially useful when the Asker and Doer are collaborating on
something the two of them haven't done together before.
Ask for early updates
This technique, like the Visualizing step, reduces mistakes by catching them early.
For example, if assigning a large task due in a week, it's reasonable to ask the Doer to
give you within 24 hours their intended work breakdown or list of tasks and steps. Don't
make this onerous; a list jotted on a napkin could be enough to clarify mutual
understanding.
Your goal as Asker is to look over this early update and see if it reveals some previously
hidden misunderstanding between you and the Doer.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 17 of 47

-- 17 of 47 --

The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition
Give context
Askers often forget how important it is for the Doer to understand what your situation
is—what the Context of your request is. When the Doer knows how you're going to use
the work product they're creating for you, they can often do it much better.
If you're buying pants and ask for cotton, don't be afraid to also share the fact that you're
planning to wear them on a hike next week. Your Doer may know reasons why cotton is
the worst fabric for next week's weather, and be able to direct you to something better.
If you want a report, make sure your Doer knows how you'll be using the report.
Suppose you ask for "a report" and what you really need is a one page summary with key
statistics in a graph, to go over with your boss. And suppose your Doer hears "report"
and gives you, at the last minute, a 20 page essay style report with data tables but no
graphs. It's like buying Ikea furniture—you have some assembly ahead of you before you
can use what you get. Better to say "a one page report I can go over with my boss in 5
minutes".
Challenge a weak YES
As Chris Voss writes in Never Split the Difference, there are three ways people say YES:
● The Confirmation YES - I confirm the truth of a statement.
○ Example: “Yes, it’s raining now.”
○ This is a weak YES.
● The Commitment YES - I willingly accept the moral burden of having you
expect me to do this thing, and I truly intend to do it.
○ Example: “Yes, I’ll pick the kids up from school today at 2 PM.”
○ This is the only strong YES.
● The Counterfeit YES - I deceive you into believing I’ve given you a
Commitment YES, but I actually have no intention of doing the task, or I haven’t
bothered to check whether it’s possible - I’m saying the word “yes” just to placate
you or postpone a hard conversation. Sometimes this is done unconsciously.
○ Example: “Yes, I’ll pick the kids up from school today at 2 PM” (when I
have no idea if I can, or if I already know I can’t).
○ This is a weak YES
To be Accountable, you should not give a Counterfeit YES and you must challenge any
YES that you wonder might be Counterfeit. A Confirmation YES is meaningless as a
form of commitment.

A person using “malicious compliance” can give a Confirmation YES and fool an Asker
into thinking they received a Strong YES.
Best Practices when you are the Doer
Do I know a better way?
As the Doer, consider whether you know of better ways to proceed. Don't let the Asker
dictate your Method if that's not appropriate. If you're not clear, or if the Asker seems to
want you to go a way that you feel isn't best, explicitly ask the Asker whether they are
willing to give you leeway to use your own judgment on the Method.
If the Asker seems determined to force you to use a Method you don't believe in, you
have options. You can for example say "If I do it my way, I will guarantee the results. If
you insist I do it your way, I cannot take responsibility for the outcome; I can only offer
you my best effort." You can also refuse to perform a task in a way you feel is wrong.
Just be clear what the basis is for your refusal—saying "I cannot agree to use a Method I
think will be harmful" is ethically sound, but merely saying "I don't want to use your
Method" can come across as contrary, willful, or insubordinate.
No weak YESes!
A "Weak YES" is any positive response to an Initiation, that serves to cut short
Negotiation before all the needed information is exchanged.
No matter whether you're the Asker or the Doer, beware of Doers (including yourself)
who say "YES" too quickly, without asking enough questions to actually understand the
work. If the Doer hasn't received enough information to actually understand what
they're supposed to do, they are unable to give informed consent—their "yes" answer is
not grounded in facts and understanding.
When this happens, it's often because the Doer feels obligated to say "yes" regardless of
circumstances, or is trying to signal loyalty, or subordination, or a willingness to help.
As the Asker, never accept a weak "yes". It's unethical to collude in creating an
agreement you don't have reason to believe can be fulfilled.
As the Doer, never give a weak "yes". It's bad practice (and hurts your reputation) to
represent to the Asker that you can do something, before you've gathered the
information to be confident you can, in fact, do it. The Doer who repeatedly gives weak
yeses will soon be mistrusted.

The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition
A better way for the Doer who wants to signal willingness, is to use the
Commit-to-Commit or the Conditional Yes moves described below. Or, one can
also simply say “I’m excited to learn all the details so I can give you a clear
commitment.”
Exception for Delegation
If your boss asks you to accept a delegation, it is appropriate to say ‘yes’ early, when you
trust that your boss will then follow up with the implementation details you need. The
boss doesn’t want to enter a lengthy Negotiation with a reluctant subordinate who might
end the Phase with a ‘no’. Delegation from your boss is development; it’s how you grow.
What else am I doing?
When you are in the Role of Doer, you already have other commitments. You may have
available time to take on new work... or you may not. Do NOT enter into a new
commitment without checking to see how it will impact existing commitments. This can
sound like, "Boss, I'm willing to do this, however I'm fully booked—can you help me
decide which of my other commitments can be delayed so I can work on this?"
If you are Asker, look for evidence of the Doer verifying they have the time to help you.
Can I commit to an Outcome, or only to Effort?
As Doer, be alert to Askers wanting you to commit to an Outcome (a definite result) in
a circumstance where you can, ethically, only commit to making an Effort.
By Outcome vs Effort here, we mean the difference between promising to "sell $1m of
product in Q3" (an Outcome) vs promising to "contact 10 new prospects a day for 90
days" (an Effort).
There's some grey area here, but the biggest reason as a Doer for agreeing only to make
an Effort is when you don't yet have a solid Method in place to produce reliable results.
By contrast, in sales especially, it's common to set quotas and otherwise rely on the skills
and professionalism of the Doer to deliver the Outcome. We expect some Doers to come
with their own Methods.
Offer visualizations and early updates
As Doer, notice if the Asker has not given you a clear Visualization (above) of the desired
end state, and has not asked for any early updates or interim deliverables.
https://txl-lab.com 	Copyright © 2024-2025 Eudae LLC. All rights reserved. 	Page 20 of 47

-- 20 of 47 --

The Accountability Protocol eBook by Thomas Cox - July 2025 Edition
As Doer, you are well within your rights to insist on an early interim deliverable as a way
to double check mutual understanding.
Commit-to-Commit and Conditional Yes
These two underused moves can signal your willingness to satisfy the Asker, but keeps
you in Negotiation.

Phase 4: Accept, Challenge, Forgive, and Learn
The final phase of the Accountability Loop is Accept. This Phase starts when the Asker
has been informed of work completion by the Doer. Now the Asker must inspect
the result and respond, informing the Doer if the Asker is content, or wishes for rework
or changes.

the other. If one feels the other has broken a significant promise, then it may be
appropriate to use the Handle a Broken Promise routine to repair the relationship.

Review routine to learn what went wrong or how we can do better next time, improving

● Which expectations were met, and did I say “thank you”?

Appendix I: Preconditions for Accountability
We know that we have Accountability when the Doer and the Asker both agree the Doer
did what the Asker asked for.
Simple as this sounds, it won’t happen on its own -- preconditions must exist. Here are
the biggest.
Ownership or Roles
We’ve all seen examples where work needs to be done, but nobody does it.
Someone proclaims that “cleaning the break room is everyone’s job!” -- all but
guaranteeing that nobody will do it. Eventually, a few hardy folks (disgusted by the
mess) will do it themselves spontaneously… but they eventually stop, feeling
unappreciated and taken advantage of by the idle majority of free riders. Unassigned
and unowned work doesn’t get done.
Less visible and possibly more toxic is Role Confusion. Wilma is convinced that it’s
Betty’s job to clean the break room, but it doesn’t get cleaned. Betty has no clue Wilma
thinks this -- nobody ever asked Betty explicitly to take that work on. Wilma may drop
hints or gossip. But until someone gets explicit about the expectations, Wilma will walk
around upset, Betty will feel vaguely disapproved of and uncomfortable… and nobody
cleans the break room.
The Asker and Doer need to have a shared understanding that there’s work to be done,
and either they both know the Asker has a role that empowers them to ask the Doer to
do it, or the two have a relationship that supports this request, or they both know that
the Doer has a role that includes this work.

table -- not because I reported to them, but because it was my job to clean tables, and I
wanted them to support me by pointing me at specific tables they wanted cleaned.
I also fully expected my boss to assign me tasks outside of my normal routine, like
picking up trash in the parking lot. Not because that was part of my job description (it
wasn’t), but because my boss had the right to assign work to me.

all of our jobs to do reasonable things for our customers.

EOS’s Accountability Chart and Apple’s DRI
Users of the Entrepreneurial Operating System (EOS) are familiar with the
“Accountability Chart” which lists all the work needed to run the firm, and allocating
responsibility for each major function to exactly one person.
A similar approach is the Directly Responsible Individual (DRI) standard adopted by
Apple.
The common theme is that “shared accountability is no accountability” -- that everyone
needs to know there is one person accountable for ensuring that a given function is
performed -- even when they may delegate some or all of the work of that function.
These are specific examples of establishing role ownership.
Basic Trust
The Accountability Protocol only works when the Asker and Doer have some baseline
level of mutual trust. This level of basic trust doesn’t need to be all that hight. Even
people who might normally mistrust each other can still come together and cooperate
effectively. (Think of the World War I Christmas cease-fires that happened
spontaneously up and down the trenches.)
If you see problems with Accountability, and it’s not caused by lack of ownership, check
for a lack of basic trust. (If two people mistrust one another enough to derail their ability
to cooperate, at least one of them will be eager to tell you.)
Clarity (Context)
In his book Conversations for Action (the inspiration for The Accountability Protocol),
Fernando Flores referred to the need to share a “context of obviousness.”
The Asker and the Doer need to share enough clarity and context to understand the
requests being made and the agreement or expectation they are creating.
If you see problems with Accountability, and the two actors have perhaps never worked
together or haven’t done this task before, check for a lack of clarity around context.

Mental Fitness (non-victimhood)
All humans can be thought of as operating in three major mental-emotional states or
modes:
● Sage mode, where one is especially calm, curious, and empathic. That person
tends to bring others into a similar state -- this is a peak-performance state.
● Sabotaged mode, where one is hijacked into a state of fear (or anger), and one
tends to bring others into a similar state. An angry boss can quickly create fear in
subordinates. This is a low-performance state.
● Neutral mode, where people are neither in Sage mode nor Sabotaged.
For as long as neither of our actors -- Asker and Doer -- are Sabotaged (they are in
Neutral or Sage mode), the Accountability Protocol can always be made to work.
If both are Sabotaged, the Accountability Protocol is unlikely to work. (But with
practice, it’s possible.)
If only one is Sabotaged, results vary. If the Sagier actor has strong mental fitness, they
can often perform well despite their partner’s state of Sabotage, and may even help
elevate that person into Neutral or Sage mode.
While dealing with Sabotaged individuals in general is beyond the scope of this book, we
include the concept because it represents a boundary condition where the Protocol will
cease to function.
In other words, a precondition for reliable usage of the Accountability Protocol is that
the two actors be Neutral or better. If you see breakdowns, you may need to check for
Sabotage.

The work being requested by the Asker must be Doable by the Doer.

Special Conditions: The Monkey’s Paw,
Work-to-Rule, and Contracts
There are boundaries beyond which you shouldn’t rely on the Accountability Protocol.
In the classic short story The Monkey’s Paw by W.W. Jacobs, a family is given three
wishes, but they find the source is dangerous and perhaps malicious. The first wish, for
money, is fulfilled when the couple’s son is killed in a workplace accident, and the
company pays a death benefit in the exact amount they wished for. (The story gets worse
from there.)
The Accountability Protocol won’t protect you from a malicious partner.
Similarly, employee unions that are legally prohibited from striking sometimes engage
in a job action known as “work-to-rule” where every instruction is followed to the letter,
and every job description is obeyed precisely. Nobody goes beyond the minimum
required by the written rules, and even obscure or outdated rules are obeyed
scrupulously. Work slows precipitously.
Here, too, the Accountability Protocol is helpless. It requires two actors working in good
faith and without another agenda.
Lastly, there’s a structural similarity between the Protocol and contract law. Legal
contracts require a structure, two (or more) parties, an agreement, performance, etc.
Legal agreements and contracts are a vital part of a functioning society.
The Accountability Protocol is a cooperative tool meant for the 90% of cases where an
Asker and a Doer can get by without a contract. It’s great when the two are trying to
figure out why their expectations aren’t being met the way they’d like, and they want to
debug and improve their working relationship.

Appendix II: Nine Saboteurs of Accountability
As taught by Shirzad Chamine in Positive Intelligence, there are exactly nine specific
and harmful ways our brains react to anxiety in ways that cause self-sabotage. This
appendix looks at how those patterns manifest specifically during an Accountability
Loop.
Every Saboteur represents the mis-use of a core character strength, hijacked by anxiety.
When you can spot these patterns in yourself or others, you can use mindfulness
techniques to interrupt the Saboteur-driven self-sabotage pattern, address the anxiety
constructively, salvage the loop, and improve the relationship.
1. Avoider
● Reacts to anxiety by hiding from facts, tasks, or conversations
● Asker: Fails to challenge weak yeses; avoids giving tough feedback.
● Doer: Doesn’t ask for help or clarification, hoping problems go away.
● This is a misuse of: easy-going flexibility and adaptability.
● Mitigation: ask “What’s needed now?” and create a small next action. Practice
sitting in discomfort and facing it without blame.
2. Controller
● Reacts to anxiety by trying to control everything.
● Asker: Dictates methods instead of negotiating outcomes; micromanages during
Perform. May be confrontational and harm relationships.
● Doer: Inflexible during Negotiate; Refuses input or changes during Perform.
● This is a misuse of: action orientation, decisiveness, and willful persistence.
● Mitigation: ask “What would make this more of a pull than a push?” Invite the
Doer to co-create the Conditions of Satisfaction with you. Ask for advice or
suggestions. Lean into the Doer’s expertise.
3. Hyper-Achiever
● Reacts to anxiety by seeking validation through achievement.
● Asker: Cares more about optics than clarity; values speed over alignment. May
under-invest in the relationship. May over-identify with success (vs learning).
● Doer: Agrees to everything for the gold star, then burns out or underdelivers. Can
over-focus on looking good and impressing others. Can lack reflection.
● Is a misuse of: practical, goal-oriented self-direction
● Mitigation: seek to enjoy the process and focus less on a given outcome.

4. Hyper-Rational
● Reacts to anxiety by over-using logic and analysis, dismissing relational needs,

● Asker: Ignores people’s needs or fails to onboard stakeholders.

remember that honoring emotional needs will make customers happier.
5. Hyper-Vigilant
● Reacts to anxiety by flooding the Loop with fear and overpreparing; breeds even
more anxiety.
● Asker: Over-specifies; re-checks everything; never trusts completion.
● Doer: Hoards updates; tries to pre-defend every move; loses focus.
● Is a misuse of: appropriate awareness of risks and dangers.
● Mitigation: Use the Eisenhower Matrix; only sweat bigger stuff.
6. Pleaser
● Reacts to anxiety by attempting to purchase goodwill by over-giving, giving a
“weak Yes”, and not attending to one’s own legitimate needs (leading to both
breakdowns and resentment).
● Asker: Avoids making real requests; over-apologizes or over-explains.
● Doer: Says yes when they mean no or still need more information; avoids
renegotiating when stuck.
● Is a misuse of: empathy, love, and the desire for connection and service.
● Mitigation: ask oneself “What would please me?” and remember to work on a
longer time horizon -- the weak Yes always leaves everyone unhappy.
7. Stickler
● Reacts to anxiety by: Focusing on trivial precision instead of the core agreement.
● Asker: Demands perfection in low-value areas; nitpicks Deliverables.
● Doer: Gets stuck perfecting formatting while missing the big picture.
● Is a misuse of: high standards of excellence and attention to detail.
● Mitigation: realize 80% of work need only be done “well enough.”
8. Restless
● Reacts to anxiety by: task switching; starting new Loops before closing existing
ones.
